question: Question_01_(b)
sols:
This statement is \textbf{false}. It reads like the conclusion of
Rolle's Theorem; however, Rolle's Theorem has two conditions: that $f$
be continuous on a closed interval (in this case the interval $[0,1]$)
and differentiable on the same open interval (in this case $(0,1)$). If
we drop either of these two conditions, then the conclusion of Rolle's
Theorem does not necessarily hold.

For example, suppose $f$ is not differentiable on $(0,1)$. Then we can
draw the picture:

\begin{figure}[htbp]
\centering
\includegraphics[width=.5\textwidth]{ScienceMathExamResourcesCoursesMath110April2011Question1cv2a.jpg}
\caption{ScienceMathExamResourcesCoursesMath110April2011Question1cv2a.jpg}
\end{figure}

While this graph satisfies $f(0) = f(1) = 1$ there is no point where the
derivative is zero, because the derivative is either 1, -1, or
undefined.

Suppose $f$ is not continuous on $[0,1]$. Then you can draw a picture
like this:

\begin{figure}[htbp]
\centering
\includegraphics[width=.5\textwidth]{ScienceMathExamResourcesCoursesMath110April2011Question1cv2b.jpg}
\caption{ScienceMathExamResourcesCoursesMath110April2011Question1cv2b.jpg}
\end{figure}

Where clearly the derivative is never zero, even though
$f(0) = f(1) = 1$.

Either example (or a similar example) would suffice to prove the
statement false.
hints:
This statement reads like the conclusion of Rolle's Theorem. Rolle's
Theorem has two conditions for $f$. What are they? What happens if a
function doesn't satisfy one of the conditions?
